test_query: Show me previous projects on medication reconciliation or reducing prescription errors using checklists or pharmacist review.
llm_output:
There are several relevant projects that focus on improving patient safety through medication reconciliation and reducing prescription errors, often involving the use of checklists or pharmacist reviews.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM054_SHP - Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
- Focuses on eliminating potential prescription errors in SengKang Polyclinic.
- Utilizes a systematic approach, possibly including checklists and pharmacist review to enhance patient safety.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM012_SHP - Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly
- Aims at improving the rate of medication errors for patients post-TBCU (Transitional Care Unit) review.
- Likely involves pharmacist reviews and checklists to ensure accurate medication reconciliation.

No other projects in the provided context specifically mention the use of checklists or pharmacist reviews, but they all aim to reduce medication incidents and improve patient safety.

section: METHODOLOGY

Content:

   - Chronic medications not ordered in one set
   - Poor documentation (such as changes to chronic medications not indicated in prescription remarks)
   - Knowledge gap of doctors on drug doses.
3. project_code: SHM_RM054
hospital: SHP
title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
PDSA1: Standardizing medication charts on computer monitors in the consultation rooms. These medication charts provided information on acceptable doses of commonly prescribed medications. The charts also served as reminders for doctors to counter check all prescriptions and to order all chronic medications together in one prescription.

PDSA2: Bi-weekly PE data were emailed to doctors. Doctors with the highest error rate were identified and separately interviewed to find out the mitigating factors and how to prevent these errors from recurring.

PDSA3: Pharmacy technicians assisted to put aside prescriptions where changes to medications were not indicated in the remarks and/or chronic medications were not ordered together in one prescription. This would reduce error in drug omission for future visits.||CHUNK 5 || SECTION: CONCLUSION || TITLE: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM054 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:
source: SHM_RM054_SHP - Enhancing patient safety by eliminating potential prescription errors in SengKang Polycli.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:18:47.684810
project_code: SHM_RM054
hospital: SHP
title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: CONCLUSION

Content:
Overall, the implementation of PDSA2 and PDSA3 achieved a significant improvement in the PE rate for Seng Kang Polyclinic. We suggest PDSA2 and PDSA3 be done monthly and to continue both interventions should it be ascertained that either or both interventions are useful in improving the PE rate with sustainability.||CHUNK 6 || SECTION: OUTCOME || TITLE: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM054 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

section: OUTCOME

Content:
PDSA1: There was no improvement in the PE rate, possibly due to new doctors who joined the clinic during that period of time.
PDSA2: The PE rates improved to <0.05% by end of January 2021, from >0.08% in December 2020, though the effect was short-lived.
PDSA3: About 6 months into its implementation, PDSA3 saw an improvement in PE rate to 0.05% in August 2021, from ≥0.08% between February to July 2021.||CHUNK 7 || SECTION: RESULTS || TITLE: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM054 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

PDSA2: The PE rates improved to <0.05% by end of January 2021, from >0.08% in December 2020, though the effect was short-lived. Many stable patients are seen at 6-monthly intervals by our doctors.

project_code: SHM_RM012
hospital: SHP
title: Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly
year: 2022
section: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS

Content:
An Ishikawa Diagram was used to analyze the cause and effect of medication errors. After a second round of voting, a Pareto chart was used to determine the top three causes (12 rule of voting).

Pareto Chart: Factors Contributing to Medications Error Post TBCU Review
- Nurses did not abide by the 6 RIGHTS when serving medications.
- Nurses were unfamiliar with Post TBCU review workflow.
- Nurses assigned to the service point after a period of time were unfamiliar to the workflow changes.||CHUNK 13 || SECTION: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS || TITLE: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM054 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

year: 2022

A Pareto chart was constructed and 5 leading causes were identified:
1. Doctors did not counter-check prescription
2. Doctors did not change drug unit/frequency
3. Chronic medications not ordered in one set
4. Poor documentation (such as changes to chronic medications not indicated in prescription remarks)
5. Knowledge gap of doctors on drug doses.||CHUNK 14 || SECTION: DISCUSSION || TITLE: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM054 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

hospital: SHP
title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: DISCUSSION

Content:
The findings indicate that while standardizing medication charts did not significantly reduce the prescription error rates (PDSA1), regular feedback and support for doctors (PDSA2) led to a short-term reduction in errors, but with sustainability issues. Long-term improvement was observed through continuous monitoring and assistance from pharmacy technicians (PDSA3).||CHUNK 15 || SECTION: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM || TITLE: Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM012 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

hospital: SHP
title: Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly
year: 2022
section: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM

Content:
Between February and December 2021, there were a total of 4 medication errors in SingHealth Polyclinics related to post-TBCU review. Bukit Merah Polyclinic had 1 such medication error.

section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
1. Team members voted for what they felt were the most likely causes.
2. A Pareto chart was constructed and 5 leading causes were identified:
   - Doctors did not counter-check prescription
   - Doctors did not change drug unit/frequency
   - Chronic medications not ordered in one set
   - Poor documentation (such as changes to chronic medications not indicated in prescription remarks)
   - Knowledge gap of doctors on drug doses.

section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
PDSA1: Standardizing medication charts on computer monitors in the consultation rooms. These medication charts provided information on acceptable doses of commonly prescribed medications. The charts also served as reminders for doctors to counter check all prescriptions and to order all chronic medications together in one prescription.

PDSA2: Bi-weekly PE data were emailed to doctors. Doctors with the highest error rate were identified and separately interviewed to find out the mitigating factors and how to prevent these errors from recurring.

PDSA3: Pharmacy technicians assisted to put aside prescriptions where changes to medications were not indicated in the remarks and/or chronic medications were not ordered together in one prescription. This would reduce error in drug omission for future visits.

section: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM

Content:
Between February and December 2021, there were a total of 4 medication errors in SingHealth Polyclinics related to post-TBCU review. Bukit Merah Polyclinic had 1 such medication error.

test_query: What methodology was used in successful projects that improved wait time perception at SKH Emergency Department?
llm_output:
The project "Re-Imagining The Patient Experience At Skh Emergency Department" (SHM_PE023) implemented several initiatives to improve the patient experience and potentially reduce perceived wait times, such as an ED Patient Dashboard for near real-time updates, SMS notifications for admission status, entertainment options like free-to-air TV, and comfort amenities including vending machines and charging points.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_PE023_SKH - Re-Imagining the Patient Experience at SKH Emergency Department
- Implementation of an ED Patient Dashboard to provide NOKs with near real-time updates on patient status.
- Enhancement of SCM system with flashing alerts for timely updates from ED staff.
- Introduction of SMS notifications to inform NOKs about admission statuses.
- Provision of free-to-air TV and vending machines for hot/cold drinks/food to keep NOKs occupied and comfortable.
- Reconfiguration of the grieving room into two separate areas for privacy and better service.

No other projects in the provided context specifically address wait time perception improvements at the Emergency Department.

hospital: SKH
title: Re-Imagining The Patient Experience At Skh Emergency Department
year: 2022
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
The PE team worked closely with Ops and ED to put structural and system enhancements in place in FY2020/FY2021. Initiatives completed in 2021 include:
- ED Patient Dashboard to provide NOKs with near real-time update of patient’s status in ED
- SCM enhancement on new column with flashing alert to alert ED doctors/nurses to provide updates to NOKs at stipulated timing
- SMS to update NOK on the admission status of the ED Patients
- Free to air TV for entertainment to keep the NOKs occupied
- Hot and cold drinks/food vending machines
- Reconfigure grieving room into 2 separate areas to provide some privacy/minimise interruption for counseling of grieving NOKs as well as to keep the toilet/water dispenser available for both staff and NOKs
- Chairs with charging points to enable NOKs to use their mobile/laptop while waiting for updates||CHUNK 2 || SECTION: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS || TITLE: Re-Imagining The Patient Experience At Skh Emergency Department || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_PE023 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

project_code: SHM_PE023
hospital: SKH
title: Re-Imagining The Patient Experience At Skh Emergency Department
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
Initiatives completed in 2021:
- ED Patient Dashboard to provide NOKs with near real-time update of patient’s status in ED
- SCM enhancement on new column with flashing alert to alert ED doctors/nurses to provide updates to NOKs at stipulated timing
- SMS to update NOK on the admission status of the ED Patients
- Free to air TV for entertainment to keep the NOKs occupied
- Hot and cold drinks/food vending machines
- Reconfigure grieving room into 2 separate areas to provide some privacy/minimise interruption for counseling of grieving NOKs as well as to keep the toilet/water dispenser available for both staff and NOKs
- Chairs with charging points to enable NOKs to use their mobile/laptop while waiting for updates

title: Re-Imagining The Patient Experience At Skh Emergency Department
year: 2022
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
The PE team worked closely with Ops and ED to put structural and system enhancements in place in FY2020/FY2021. Initiatives completed in 2021 include:
- ED Patient Dashboard to provide NOKs with near real-time update of patient’s status in ED
- SCM enhancement on new column with flashing alert to alert ED doctors/nurses to provide updates to NOKs at stipulated timing
- SMS to update NOK on the admission status of the ED Patients
- Free to air TV for entertainment to keep the NOKs occupied
- Hot and cold drinks/food vending machines
- Reconfigure grieving room into 2 separate areas to provide some privacy/minimise interruption for counseling of grieving NOKs as well as to keep the toilet/water dispenser available for both staff and NOKs
- Chairs with charging points to enable NOKs to use their mobile/laptop while waiting for updates

test_query: How did previous QIPs measure improvement in reducing inpatient falls due to toileting needs or ambulation support?
llm_output:
Previous Quality Improvement Projects (QIPs) measured improvements in reducing inpatient falls by tracking fall rates and specific outcomes related to toileting needs and patient mobilization. For instance, one project achieved a 57% reduction in falls related to toileting needs, while another noted an increase in safe active mobilization among patients.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM001_SKH - Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need
- Reduction of 57% falls related to toileting needs.
- Fall rate reduced from a baseline average of 0.63 to a current average of 0.27.
- Achieved zero falls for five consecutive months.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
- 93% reduction in the use of commodes.
- 86% increase in patient ambulation within the ward.
- No fall cases occurred when mobilizing patients out of bed or transferring between bed and geriatric chair during the study period.

test_query: What steps did successful QIPs take to implement multi-disciplinary interventions targeting medication error reduction?
llm_output:
Successful Quality Improvement Projects (QIPs) implemented a variety of multi-disciplinary interventions to reduce medication errors, including forming workgroups for root cause analysis and corrective actions, publishing safety bulletins, identifying ward champions, and involving medical teams in scheduling medications. These projects also included training modules and the use of technology to enhance communication and accuracy.

    PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM045_SCH - Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)
    - A medication safety workgroup was formed to analyze incidents with root cause analysis.
    - Monthly medication safety bulletins were published to share best practices.
    - Medication safety champions at each ward were identified to reinforce correct procedures and create awareness.
    - Complicated medications scheduling in SCM is done by the medical team, verified by pharmacists.

    PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM053_SCH - Reduce Medication Rate At Skch To Below 0.3 Per 1000 Patient Days (Ch Average) Over 1Yr
    - Ward pharmacy and nursing teams perform handover to account for medications.
    - Monthly checks on expiry dates of ward stock by the Alps team.
    - Implementation of non-alphabetical bin locations at pharmacy to address wrong supply from formulary.
    - Disabling auto-perfection function in SCM to prevent system errors.
    - Nursing-in-house training modules established for medication management.
    - Medication safety champions identified and trained to reinforce correct practices.

    PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM054_SHP - Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
    - Standardizing medication charts on computer monitors in consultation rooms.
    - Bi-weekly PE data emailed to doctors for error rate analysis and interviews with high-error-rate doctors.
    - Pharmacy technicians assisting in identifying prescriptions that need changes.

    PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM012_SHP - Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly
    - Creation of a new checklist for nurses to use as a visual reference.
    - Nurses provided feedback on the checklist, leading to its enhancement.
    - Polls conducted to assess and improve the effectiveness of treatment room checklists.

project_code: SHM_RM012

title: Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
### Goals:
1. To ensure all nurses utilize the checklist as a visual reference.
2. To reinforce nurses on checking the 6 Rights on every medication administration.

#### Intervention 1
A new checklist was created to include the patient's name, NRIC, review date, drug regimen, nurse's name and signature.

#### Intervention 2
Nurses provided comments on how to enhance the checklist. A new checklist was subsequently produced including items such as the patient's DOT registration number and the expected date of review return.

#### Intervention 3
A poll was conducted to assess the effectiveness of the treatment room checklist. To improve visibility and accountability, the listing items of the checklist were rearranged.||CHUNK 8 || SECTION: OUTCOME || TITLE: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och) || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SCH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM045 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

The OCH medication rate had been reduced to 0.79 per 1000 patient days from Jun 20 to May 21, achieving a significant reduction of almost 50%.

test_query: What metrics were used to evaluate the effectiveness of WhatsApp bot interventions for pre-surgical education?
llm_output:
No relevant projects found in current documents.

The provided context does not contain information about any project or evaluation metrics related to WhatsApp bot interventions for pre-surgical education in 2025. The available document is from 2022 and focuses on patient experience improvements via a WhatsApp communication channel, but it does not specify details about pre-surgical education or the year 2025.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_PE035_SHHQ - Improve Patient Experience And Engage Patient Seamlessly Via Whatsapp Communication Channel
- Survey respondents agreed that the bot helped reassure them and reduced anxiety.
- Patients were satisfied with receiving information via the bot.
- The bot saved clarification time, reducing dwell time by approximately 10% in education counseling sessions.
- Respondents indicated they would recommend the bot to other patients.

However, this project does not specifically address pre-surgical education or metrics used for evaluation in 2025.

test_query: How was success measured in reducing prescription errors in Seng Kang Polyclinic or near misses at Bedok Polyclinic?
llm_output:
The success of the projects was measured through changes in error rates. For Seng Kang Polyclinic, potential prescription error (PE) rates were monitored over time to assess improvements. At Bedok Polyclinic, pharmacy near miss rates due to wrong drugs and dosage forms/strengths were analyzed before and after implementing a bin coding system.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM054_SHP - Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
- PE rate was monitored over time.
- PDSA cycles (Plan-Do-Study-Act) were used to measure the effectiveness of interventions.
- Initial PDSA1 showed no improvement, but subsequent PDSAs demonstrated a reduction in PE rates.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM055_SHP - Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
- Monthly near miss rates due to wrong drugs and dosage forms/strengths were analyzed.
- The implementation of the bin coding system led to a noticeable improvement in error rates, with specific reductions noted from July 2021 onwards.

project_code: SHM_RM055
hospital: SHP
title: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
year: 2022
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
A bin coding system was identified as a possible solution to reduce the picking of wrong drugs and dosage forms/strengths. Each drug storage tray was assigned a unique bin address. A Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycle was carried out from 1st August 2021 to 31st October 2021:
- Set up bin location in the planogram template.
- Pharmacy Technicians pick medications based on the bin code on each drug label.
- Collate and analyze near miss reports every month for three months.||CHUNK 7 || SECTION: BACKGROUND || TITLE: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM055 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

project_code: SHM_RM055
hospital: SHP
title: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
year: 2022
section: BACKGROUND

Content:
A near miss is an error or incident that is detected and prevented before reaching the patient. If such an error is undetected and goes to the patient, it may potentially lead to an adverse drug event and cause harm to the patient.

SHP-Bedok is a fast-paced primary care polyclinic with a high patient load. The number of pharmacy near misses had escalated in June and July 2021 compared to earlier months in the same year. These near misses occurred during the picking stage of the drug preparation process. Possible causes are high patient workload, constant interruptions, and staff fatigue.

Newly employed staff and relief staff from other polyclinics have difficulties locating and picking the medications due to drugs not being arranged according to their therapeutic indication in the pharmacy. In addition, staff who were familiar with the location of the drugs in the pharmacy tended to rely on memory to locate and pick medications to fill the prescriptions. However, mental fatigue could result in staff experiencing a lapse or slip in memory, thus picking the wrong drug, dosage form, or strength and resulting in an error.||CHUNK 8 || SECTION: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS || TITLE: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM055 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

High patient load and interruptions contribute to staff fatigue, leading to reliance on memory rather than specific locations for medication. This reliance can result in errors when picking the wrong drug, dosage form, or strength due to lapses in memory.||CHUNK 9 || SECTION: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM || TITLE: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM055 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
A bin coding system was identified as a possible solution to reduce the picking of wrong drugs and dosage forms/strengths. Each drug storage tray was assigned a unique bin address. A Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycle was carried out from 1st August 2021 to 31st October 2021:
- Set up bin location in the planogram template.
- Pharmacy Technicians pick medications based on the bin code on each drug label.
- Collate and analyze near miss reports every month for three months.

section: BACKGROUND

Content:
A near miss is an error or incident that is detected and prevented before reaching the patient. If such an error is undetected and goes to the patient, it may potentially lead to an adverse drug event and cause harm to the patient.

SHP-Bedok is a fast-paced primary care polyclinic with a high patient load. The number of pharmacy near misses had escalated in June and July 2021 compared to earlier months in the same year. These near misses occurred during the picking stage of the drug preparation process. Possible causes are high patient workload, constant interruptions, and staff fatigue.

Newly employed staff and relief staff from other polyclinics have difficulties locating and picking the medications due to drugs not being arranged according to their therapeutic indication in the pharmacy. In addition, staff who were familiar with the location of the drugs in the pharmacy tended to rely on memory to locate and pick medications to fill the prescriptions. However, mental fatigue could result in staff experiencing a lapse or slip in memory, thus picking the wrong drug, dosage form, or strength and resulting in an error.

A bin coding system was implemented where each drug storage tray had a unique address. Placement of fast-moving drugs was reviewed to facilitate efficient and accurate picking, before setting up bin locations in the Pharmacy System.

test_query: What were the main findings from projects that used visual reminders to prevent specimen mislabeling in CGH or OCH?
llm_output:
The project at CGH (Clementine General Hospital) found that implementing a new visual indicator significantly reduced and prevented specimen errors by ensuring all staff noticed and adhered to proper labelling guidelines.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM022_CGH - Zero Error
- Post-implementation survey results showed high visibility of the new visual indicators among 32 nurses, 15 doctors, and 2 phlebotomists.
- The implementation led to zero incidents of mislabelling since July 2021.
- Key features included eye-catching visuals, clear wording, unmissable location, and blinking lights for day and night visibility.

section: BACKGROUND

Content:
Identifying correct patient and correct labelling specimen are critical to patient’s safety. If a specimen is identified or labelled wrongly, it can lead to wrong diagnosis, treatment to the wrong patient, blood transfusion errors and more. It can also have significant consequences in patient care including delay in treatments, requiring additional laboratory tests and increasing healthcare costs which are preventable.

test_query: How did staff surveys reflect the success of medication checklists or mobility signage interventions?
llm_output:
Staff surveys reflected that medication checklists helped improve focus and efficiency during medication administration, leading to no reported medication errors post-TBCU review. For mobility signage, surveys indicated increased patient mobilization and a reduction in the use of diapers and commodes.

PROJECT TITLE: Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly (SHM_RM012_SHP)
- Staff reported that checklists helped them be more focused and efficient during medication administration.
- No report of medication error among post-TBCU reviewed patients.

PROJECT TITLE: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls (SHM_CO005_SKH)
- 67% reduction in the use of diapers reported by nursing staff.
- 93% reduction in the use of commodes.
- 86% of respondents ambulated patients more often with mobility signage.

Content:
### Goals:
1. To ensure all nurses utilize the checklist as a visual reference.
2. To reinforce nurses on checking the 6 Rights on every medication administration.

A new checklist was created to include the patient's name, NRIC, review date, drug regimen, nurse's name and signature.

#### Intervention 2
Nurses provided comments on how to enhance the checklist. A new checklist was subsequently produced including items such as the patient's DOT registration number and the expected date of review return.

project_code: SHM_RM045
hospital: SCH
title: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The project team brainstormed and came out with the following interventions:
1. A medication safety workgroup was formed to look into all medication safety related issues. Incidents were discussed with root cause analysis, and corrective actions were proposed at workgroup level.
2. SCH monthly medication safety bulletin has been published to share best practices and correct procedures to ensure medication safety.
3. Medication safety vest was piloted in selected OCH wards with the aim to reduce disruptions during medication administration. The intervention was not implemented due to unsatisfactory pilot results.
4. To implement a “status board” in SCM as a “live” board to keep staff updated on the list of tasks for patients.
5. Medication safety champions at each ward were identified to further reduce the risk of medication incidents. The champions will reinforce correct procedures to ground staff and create awareness. At the same time, they will communicate with their colleagues on new medication practices if any.
6. Complicated medications scheduling in SCM will be scheduled by the medical team, which will then be verified by pharmacists prior to nursing administration.||CHUNK 4 || SECTION: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES || TITLE: Reduce Medication Rate At Skch To Below 0.3 Per 1000 Patient Days (Ch Average) Over 1Yr || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SCH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM053 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:
source: SHM_RM053_SCH - Reduce medication rate at SKCH to below 0.3 per 1000 patient days (CH average) over 1yr.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:17:42.230879
project_code: SHM_RM053
hospital: SCH
title: Reduce Medication Rate At Skch To Below 0.3 Per 1000 Patient Days (Ch Average) Over 1Yr
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
1. In reducing omission due to medications stock not available in SKCH or SKH pharmacy, the ward pharmacy and nursing team will perform handover to account for the number of medications left in the patient’s medication box.
2. Alps team will check expiry date of ward stock every month and expiring items are removed 3 months prior to expiry for safety purpose.
3. Wrong supply from formulary was addressed by implementing non alphabetical bin location at pharmacy.
4. Auto-perfection function in SCM was disabled to prevent system auto select lowest dose for verification which lead to downstream wrong labelling of patients own medications.
5. Nursing-in house training modules established to train nursing staff on medication management.
6. Sharing of medication incident with learning points to all staff via monthly bulletin.
7. The use of medication vest was also piloted in the ward.
8. Medication safety champions at each ward were identified and they will reinforce correct practices to ground staff and create awareness.
9. Complicated medications scheduling in SCM is done by medical, which will then be verified by pharmacist prior to nursing administration.||CHUNK 5 || SECTION: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES || TITLE: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls || YEAR: 2024 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_CO005 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

test_query: How was a bin code system implemented to reduce near misses during drug picking in Bedok Polyclinic?
llm_output:
A bin coding system was implemented at Bedok Polyclinic by assigning unique addresses to each drug storage tray, which helped pharmacy technicians pick medications accurately based on the bin codes. This system reduced the likelihood of picking wrong drugs or incorrect dosage forms/strengths.

PROJECT TITLE: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic (SHM_RM055_SHP)
- Each drug storage tray was assigned a unique bin address.
- A Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycle was conducted from August 1, 2021 to October 31, 2021.
- Near miss reports were collated and analyzed monthly for three months.

title: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
year: 2022
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
A bin coding system was identified as a possible solution to reduce the picking of wrong drugs and dosage forms/strengths. Each drug storage tray was assigned a unique bin address. A Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycle was carried out from 1st August 2021 to 31st October 2021:
- Set up bin location in the planogram template.
- Pharmacy Technicians pick medications based on the bin code on each drug label.
- Collate and analyze near miss reports every month for three months.||CHUNK 3 || SECTION: INTRODUCTION || TITLE: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM055 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

hospital: SHP
title: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
year: 2022
section: BACKGROUND

Content:
A near miss is an error or incident that is detected and prevented before reaching the patient. If such an error is undetected and goes to the patient, it may potentially lead to an adverse drug event and cause harm to the patient.

SHP-Bedok is a fast-paced primary care polyclinic with a high patient load. The number of pharmacy near misses had escalated in June and July 2021 compared to earlier months in the same year. These near misses occurred during the picking stage of the drug preparation process. Possible causes are high patient workload, constant interruptions, and staff fatigue.

Newly employed staff and relief staff from other polyclinics have difficulties locating and picking the medications due to drugs not being arranged according to their therapeutic indication in the pharmacy. In addition, staff who were familiar with the location of the drugs in the pharmacy tended to rely on memory to locate and pick medications to fill the prescriptions. However, mental fatigue could result in staff experiencing a lapse or slip in memory, thus picking the wrong drug, dosage form, or strength and resulting in an error.||CHUNK 8 || SECTION: OUTCOME || TITLE: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM055 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

Content:
The implementation of the bin coding system helped in reducing reliance on memory to locate correct medications, thereby minimizing near misses due to wrong drugs and dosage forms/strengths during picking at SHP-Bedok pharmacy. This resulted in a noticeable improvement in error rates following its introduction.||CHUNK 9 || SECTION: RESULTS || TITLE: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM055 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

project_code: SHM_RM055
hospital: SHP
title: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
year: 2022
section: RESULTS

Content:
Pharmacy monthly near misses rates due to wrong drug and dosage forms/strengths were analyzed from May 2021 to October 2021. The overall near miss rate improved after implementing the bin coding system in August 2021. Specifically:
- Near miss rate fell from 0.031% (Jul) to 0.029% (Aug), 0.019% (Sep), and 0.018% (Oct).
- Improvement was greater for wrong dosage forms/strengths compared to wrong drugs.||CHUNK 10 || SECTION: SUSTAINABILITY AND SPREAD || TITLE: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM055 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

title: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic
year: 2022

For long-term sustainability, ongoing training and reinforcement on the use of bin codes are necessary. Adjustments can continue based on staff feedback and regular review of medication placement. The success of this intervention could be spread to other clinics facing similar issues.||CHUNK 11 || SECTION: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM || TITLE: Implementation Of Bin Code Location To Reduce Pharmacy Near Misses In Bedok Polyclinic || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM055 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
A bin coding system was identified as a possible solution to reduce the picking of wrong drugs and dosage forms/strengths. Each drug storage tray was assigned a unique bin address. A Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycle was carried out from 1st August 2021 to 31st October 2021:
- Set up bin location in the planogram template.
- Pharmacy Technicians pick medications based on the bin code on each drug label.
- Collate and analyze near miss reports every month for three months.

section: BACKGROUND

Content:
A near miss is an error or incident that is detected and prevented before reaching the patient. If such an error is undetected and goes to the patient, it may potentially lead to an adverse drug event and cause harm to the patient.

SHP-Bedok is a fast-paced primary care polyclinic with a high patient load. The number of pharmacy near misses had escalated in June and July 2021 compared to earlier months in the same year. These near misses occurred during the picking stage of the drug preparation process. Possible causes are high patient workload, constant interruptions, and staff fatigue.

Newly employed staff and relief staff from other polyclinics have difficulties locating and picking the medications due to drugs not being arranged according to their therapeutic indication in the pharmacy. In addition, staff who were familiar with the location of the drugs in the pharmacy tended to rely on memory to locate and pick medications to fill the prescriptions. However, mental fatigue could result in staff experiencing a lapse or slip in memory, thus picking the wrong drug, dosage form, or strength and resulting in an error.

section: RESULTS

Content:
Pharmacy monthly near misses rates due to wrong drug and dosage forms/strengths were analyzed from May 2021 to October 2021. The overall near miss rate improved after implementing the bin coding system in August 2021. Specifically:
- Near miss rate fell from 0.031% (Jul) to 0.029% (Aug), 0.019% (Sep), and 0.018% (Oct).
- Improvement was greater for wrong dosage forms/strengths compared to wrong drugs.

test_query: What specific PDSA interventions were tested to reduce prescription error rates at Seng Kang Polyclinic?
llm_output:
The specific PDSA (Plan-Do-Study-Act) interventions tested to reduce prescription error rates at Sengkang Polyclinic included standardizing medication charts on computer monitors, bi-weekly emailing of performance data to doctors for targeted interviews with those having the highest error rates, and pharmacy technicians assisting in identifying prescriptions that required changes or were not ordered together.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM054_SHP - Enhancing patient safety by eliminating potential prescription errors in SengKang Polycli
- PDSA1: Standardizing medication charts on computer monitors to provide dose information and reminders for doctors.
- PDSA2: Bi-weekly emailing of performance data to doctors, with targeted interviews for those with the highest error rates.
- PDSA3: Pharmacy technicians assisting in identifying prescriptions that required changes or were not ordered together.

project_code: SHM_RM054
hospital: SHP
title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
PDSA1: Standardizing medication charts on computer monitors in the consultation rooms. These medication charts provided information on acceptable doses of commonly prescribed medications. The charts also served as reminders for doctors to counter check all prescriptions and to order all chronic medications together in one prescription.

PDSA2: Bi-weekly PE data were emailed to doctors. Doctors with the highest error rate were identified and separately interviewed to find out the mitigating factors and how to prevent these errors from recurring.

PDSA3: Pharmacy technicians assisted to put aside prescriptions where changes to medications were not indicated in the remarks and/or chronic medications were not ordered together in one prescription. This would reduce error in drug omission for future visits.||CHUNK 2 || SECTION: DISCUSSION || TITLE: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM054 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:18:47.684810
project_code: SHM_RM054
hospital: SHP
title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: DISCUSSION

Content:
The findings indicate that while standardizing medication charts did not significantly reduce the prescription error rates (PDSA1), regular feedback and support for doctors (PDSA2) led to a short-term reduction in errors, but with sustainability issues. Long-term improvement was observed through continuous monitoring and assistance from pharmacy technicians (PDSA3).||CHUNK 3 || SECTION: METHODOLOGY || TITLE: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM054 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

hospital: SHP
title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
1. Team members voted for what they felt were the most likely causes.
2. A Pareto chart was constructed and 5 leading causes were identified:
   - Doctors did not counter-check prescription
   - Doctors did not change drug unit/frequency
   - Chronic medications not ordered in one set
   - Poor documentation (such as changes to chronic medications not indicated in prescription remarks)
   - Knowledge gap of doctors on drug doses.
3. A series of 3 PDSA (Plan-Do-Study-Act) cycles were conducted from October 2020 to March 2021 to address these common causes.||CHUNK 4 || SECTION: SUSTAINABILITY AND SPREAD || TITLE: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM054 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: SUSTAINABILITY AND SPREAD

Content:
Overall, the implementation of PDSA2 and PDSA3 achieved significant improvements in prescription error rates for Seng Kang Polyclinic. We suggest that these interventions be conducted monthly to sustainably improve PE rate.||CHUNK 5 || SECTION: BACKGROUND || TITLE: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SHP || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM054 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
PDSA1: Standardizing medication charts on computer monitors in the consultation rooms. These medication charts provided information on acceptable doses of commonly prescribed medications. The charts also served as reminders for doctors to counter check all prescriptions and to order all chronic medications together in one prescription.

PDSA2: Bi-weekly PE data were emailed to doctors. Doctors with the highest error rate were identified and separately interviewed to find out the mitigating factors and how to prevent these errors from recurring.

PDSA3: Pharmacy technicians assisted to put aside prescriptions where changes to medications were not indicated in the remarks and/or chronic medications were not ordered together in one prescription. This would reduce error in drug omission for future visits.
chunk_2:
[section: DISCUSSION, project_code: SHM_RM054, year: 2022, hospital: SHP, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:
source: SHM_RM054_SHP - Enhancing patient safety by eliminating potential prescription errors in SengKang Polycli.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:18:47.684810
project_code: SHM_RM054
hospital: SHP
title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: DISCUSSION

Content:
The findings indicate that while standardizing medication charts did not significantly reduce the prescription error rates (PDSA1), regular feedback and support for doctors (PDSA2) led to a short-term reduction in errors, but with sustainability issues. Long-term improvement was observed through continuous monitoring and assistance from pharmacy technicians (PDSA3).
chunk_3:
[section: METHODOLOGY, project_code: SHM_RM054, year: 2022, hospital: SHP, relevance: 0.6] Metadata:
source: SHM_RM054_SHP - Enhancing patient safety by eliminating potential prescription errors in SengKang Polycli.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:18:47.684810
project_code: SHM_RM054
hospital: SHP
title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
1. Team members voted for what they felt were the most likely causes.
2. A Pareto chart was constructed and 5 leading causes were identified:
   - Doctors did not counter-check prescription
   - Doctors did not change drug unit/frequency
   - Chronic medications not ordered in one set
   - Poor documentation (such as changes to chronic medications not indicated in prescription remarks)
   - Knowledge gap of doctors on drug doses.
3. A series of 3 PDSA (Plan-Do-Study-Act) cycles were conducted from October 2020 to March 2021 to address these common causes.
chunk_4:
[section: SUSTAINABILITY AND SPREAD, project_code: SHM_RM054, year: 2022, hospital: SHP, relevance: 0.6] Metadata:
source: SHM_RM054_SHP - Enhancing patient safety by eliminating potential prescription errors in SengKang Polycli.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:18:47.684810
project_code: SHM_RM054
hospital: SHP
title: Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
year: 2022
section: SUSTAINABILITY AND SPREAD

Content:
Overall, the implementation of PDSA2 and PDSA3 achieved significant improvements in prescription error rates for Seng Kang Polyclinic. We suggest that these interventions be conducted monthly to sustainably improve PE rate.

test_query: What metrics were commonly used to evaluate fall prevention interventions?
llm_output:
Fall rates per 1000 patient days were commonly used to evaluate the effectiveness of fall prevention interventions in the projects reviewed. This metric was utilized to measure reductions in falls across different wards and hospitals.

PROJECT TITLE: Reduce Fall Rate Of All Patients At Skch To Less Than 0.99 Patient Fall Per 1000Patients (SHM_RM052)
- The project aimed to reduce fall rates below 0.99 per 1000 patient days.
- Interventions were piloted in high-risk wards and then spread hospital-wide after showing effectiveness.

PROJECT TITLE: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls (SHM_CO005)
- While this project focused on safe mobilization, it indirectly contributed to fall prevention by reducing the use of commodes and increasing patient ambulation.
- Fall rates were not directly measured in this project.

PROJECT TITLE: Reducing Inpatient Falls In Och (SHM_RM044)
- The project reported a reduction in fall rate to 0.80 per 1,000 patient days from June 2020 to May 2021.
- This metric was used to evaluate the success of interventions aimed at reducing falls among inpatients.

project_code: SHM_RM052
hospital: SCH
title: Reduce Fall Rate Of All Patients At Skch To Less Than 0.99 Patient Fall Per 1000Patients
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
1. Established high fall wards for patients with high risk of falling.
2. Fall prevention brochures were printed for distribution to Next of Kin (NOK) in all wards.
3. The rehab team created A3 mobility board and abbreviation form to guide the nursing staff on patient’s mobility status.
4. The medical team conducted postural blood pressure assessment for new admissions.
5. Fall prevention script and education for patient and NOK was established.
6. Nursing grand fall rounds helped to educate staff on fall prevention measures in a timely manner.
7. Fall champions appointed in the wards helped to strengthen the fall prevalence efforts by the nurses.
8. Rehab team established fall Prevention Booklet/Guide for patient/NOK.
9. The walk steady award was implemented to recognize ward with zero falls on that month. The ward with zero falls for consecutive 3 months would receive Walk Steady CEO Fall Free Award.
10. Sharing of successful fall prevention measures and fall champions’ effort in reducing fall rates in In’sync publication.||CHUNK 5 || SECTION: METHODOLOGY || TITLE: Reduce Fall Rate Of All Patients At Skch To Less Than 0.99 Patient Fall Per 1000Patients || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SCH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM052 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

test_query: How was patient or staff feedback quantitatively measured in successful QIPs?
llm_output:
Patient and staff feedback were quantitatively measured through various metrics such as satisfaction scores, reduction in complaints, and time savings. For instance, improvements in waiting times and willingness to recommend were tracked at SKH Emergency Department, while the use of a WhatsApp communication channel led to significant patient reassurance and reduced anxiety levels. Additionally, the implementation of robotic process automation for collecting patient-reported outcome measures resulted in substantial time savings.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_PE023_SKH - Re-Imagining The Patient Experience At Skh Emergency Department
- Waiting Time To See Doctor (very reasonable/somewhat reasonable): 75.3% to 90.7%
- Empowerment & Care Transition (always, usually): 89.4% to 92.9%
- Willingness to Recommend (always, usually): 86.0% to 92.0%

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_PE035_SHHQ - Improve Patient Experience And Engage Patient Seamlessly Via Whatsapp Communication Channel
- The Project/Bot helped to reassure patients and reduced their level of anxiety.
- Patients were happy with the Bot and receiving information via it.
- The Bot saved clarification time, reducing dwell time by ~10% in education counselling sessions.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_OP077_SGH - Use Of Robotic Process Automation In The Collection Of Patient-Reported Outcome Measures
- Total saved: 31,464 mins / $22,559.69.
- Ongoing monthly savings: 8631 mins / $6188.72 (based on current response rate).

processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:03:22.514995
project_code: SHM_OP077
hospital: SGH
title: Use Of Robotic Process Automation In The Collection Of Patient-Reported Outcome Measures
year: 2022
section: DISCUSSION

Content:
The utility of RPA in automating the PROMs collection has been demonstrated effectively. The project not only freed up clinical time for physiotherapists but also reduced unnecessary cognitive work required to calculate PROMs scores, thus allowing more time for patient care and personalized treatment planning.

Building on this success, future initiatives include improving response rates from patients and expanding RPA use across other healthcare specialties to reduce the burden on HCPs while delivering patient-centric value-based healthcare.

year: 2022
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
1. **Define project goals** and deliverables.
2. **Explore & Design**: Insights gathering via survey and interview with patients, caregivers and staff to meet requirements.
3. **Develop & Iterate**: 98% of respondents had WhatsApp in their smartphone according to the survey (n = 60). 
4. **Deploy & Refine**: Pilot, gather insights and refine solution to meet needs of patients, caregivers and staff.

project_code: SHM_PE035
hospital: SHHQ
title: Improve Patient Experience And Engage Patient Seamlessly Via Whatsapp Communication Channel
year: 2022
section: CONCLUSION

Content:
The multi-disciplinary team has demonstrated the importance of gaining insights from patients and caregivers (i.e., users), conceptualized a solution for the pilot, solicited feedback on the solution while making it relevant to their patients. The multi-lingual Bot coupled with useful information via WhatsApp has addressed frequently asked questions and concerns from patients, reducing anxiety for their planned surgery. This project's success was made possible by the great team spirit and support from various stakeholders.

processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:03:22.514995
project_code: SHM_OP077
hospital: SGH
title: Use Of Robotic Process Automation In The Collection Of Patient-Reported Outcome Measures
year: 2022
section: DISCUSSION

Content:
The utility of RPA in automating the PROMs collection has been demonstrated effectively. The project not only freed up clinical time for physiotherapists but also reduced unnecessary cognitive work required to calculate PROMs scores, thus allowing more time for patient care and personalized treatment planning.

Building on this success, future initiatives include improving response rates from patients and expanding RPA use across other healthcare specialties to reduce the burden on HCPs while delivering patient-centric value-based healthcare.

test_query: How did they define success in patient engagement initiatives.
llm_output:
The projects defined success in patient engagement initiatives through various metrics such as patient satisfaction, reduction in anxiety levels, time saved on clarifications, and willingness to recommend the service to others. For instance, one project measured success by the percentage of patients who reported a positive experience with a WhatsApp communication bot, while another evaluated success based on overall satisfaction scores from distress screening programs.

    PROJECT TITLE: SHM_PE035_SHHQ - Improve Patient Experience And Engage Patient Seamlessly Via Whatsapp Communication Channel
    - 100% of survey respondents agreed that the project helped reassure them and reduced their anxiety.
    - Patients were happy with receiving information via the bot, which saved clarification time.
    - The multi-disciplinary team demonstrated the importance of gaining insights from patients to improve engagement.

    PROJECT TITLE: SHM_PE051_NCCS - Patient Acceptability N Satisfaction
    - Participants reported positive experiences with the ACCESS Programme, especially those who had contact with SCNs.
    - High satisfaction levels were noted regarding SCN interactions and support provided.
    - A significant percentage of respondents indicated they would recommend the programme to others.

title: Re-Imagining The Patient Experience At Skh Emergency Department
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
Initiatives completed in 2021:
- ED Patient Dashboard to provide NOKs with near real-time update of patient’s status in ED
- SCM enhancement on new column with flashing alert to alert ED doctors/nurses to provide updates to NOKs at stipulated timing
- SMS to update NOK on the admission status of the ED Patients
- Free to air TV for entertainment to keep the NOKs occupied
- Hot and cold drinks/food vending machines
- Reconfigure grieving room into 2 separate areas to provide some privacy/minimise interruption for counseling of grieving NOKs as well as to keep the toilet/water dispenser available for both staff and NOKs
- Chairs with charging points to enable NOKs to use their mobile/laptop while waiting for updates

test_query: What indicators were used to assess medication safety in community hospitals or polyclinics?
llm_output:
The indicators used to assess medication safety in community hospitals or polyclinics include the rate of medication incidents and the rate of prescription errors.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM053_SCH - Reduce Medication Rate At Skch To Below 0.3 Per 1000 Patient Days (Ch Average) Over 1Yr
- Collaboration between medical, nursing, and pharmacy teams.
- Implementing specific interventions such as periodic expiry date checks, non-alphabetical bin locations at pharmacy, disabling auto-perfection in SCM.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM045_SCH - Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)
- A medication safety workgroup was formed to look into all medication safety-related issues.
- SCH monthly medication safety bulletin has been published to share best practices and correct procedures to ensure medication safety.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM054_SHP - Enhancing Patient Safety By Eliminating Potential Prescription Errors In Sengkang Polycli
- Team members voted for what they felt were the most likely causes.
- A Pareto chart was constructed and 5 leading causes were identified, including doctors not counter-checking prescriptions and poor documentation.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM012_SHP - Improving The Rate Of Medication Error For Patients Post Tbcu Review At Bukit Merah Poly
- An Ishikawa Diagram was used to analyze the cause and effect of medication errors.
- A Pareto chart was used to determine the top three causes after a second round of voting.

project_code: SHM_RM045
hospital: SCH
title: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The project team brainstormed and came out with the following interventions:
1. A medication safety workgroup was formed to look into all medication safety related issues. Incidents were discussed with root cause analysis, and corrective actions were proposed at workgroup level.
2. SCH monthly medication safety bulletin has been published to share best practices and correct procedures to ensure medication safety.
3. Medication safety vest was piloted in selected OCH wards with the aim to reduce disruptions during medication administration. The intervention was not implemented due to unsatisfactory pilot results.
4. To implement a “status board” in SCM as a “live” board to keep staff updated on the list of tasks for patients.
5. Medication safety champions at each ward were identified to further reduce the risk of medication incidents. The champions will reinforce correct procedures to ground staff and create awareness. At the same time, they will communicate with their colleagues on new medication practices if any.
6. Complicated medications scheduling in SCM will be scheduled by the medical team, which will then be verified by pharmacists prior to nursing administration.||CHUNK 2 || SECTION: INTRODUCTION || TITLE: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och) || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SCH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM045 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

section: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS

Content:
Root Causes of Medication Events

| Root Cause                         | Percentage |
|------------------------------------|------------|
| Lack of awareness on medication safety        | 15%       |
| No / lack of proper handover practices during verification of medication order  | 13%      |
| Staff lack of knowledge             | 80%         |
| Lack of training or work instruction            | -          |
| Lack of system prompt               | -           |
| Insufficient guidance in cubicle (early morning)   | -        |||CHUNK 12 || SECTION: CONCLUSION || TITLE: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och) || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SCH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM045 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

title: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The project team brainstormed and came out with the following interventions:
1. A medication safety workgroup was formed to look into all medication safety related issues. Incidents were discussed with root cause analysis, and corrective actions were proposed at workgroup level.
2. SCH monthly medication safety bulletin has been published to share best practices and correct procedures to ensure medication safety.
3. Medication safety vest was piloted in selected OCH wards with the aim to reduce disruptions during medication administration. The intervention was not implemented due to unsatisfactory pilot results.
4. To implement a “status board” in SCM as a “live” board to keep staff updated on the list of tasks for patients.
5. Medication safety champions at each ward were identified to further reduce the risk of medication incidents. The champions will reinforce correct procedures to ground staff and create awareness. At the same time, they will communicate with their colleagues on new medication practices if any.
6. Complicated medications scheduling in SCM will be scheduled by the medical team, which will then be verified by pharmacists prior to nursing administration.

section: DISCUSSION

While the project team saw significant improvement in reducing the medication incident rates through various interventions like the formation of a medication safety workgroup and the implementation of monthly bulletins, some proposed solutions such as the use of a medication safety vest were not viable due to unsatisfactory pilot results.

section: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS

Content:
Root Causes of Medication Events

| Root Cause                         | Percentage |
|------------------------------------|------------|
| Lack of awareness on medication safety        | 15%       |
| No / lack of proper handover practices during verification of medication order  | 13%      |
| Staff lack of knowledge             | 80%         |
| Lack of training or work instruction            | -          |
| Lack of system prompt               | -           |
| Insufficient guidance in cubicle (early morning)   | -        |

section: CONCLUSION

Content:
Through the formation of a workgroup, regular communication via bulletins, and champion initiatives, the OCH medication incident rate was significantly reduced. The sustainability and spread strategies ensure ongoing compliance with safety practices.

Content:
The workgroup has implemented the following interventions:
1. Established a high fall ward for patients with high fall risk.
2. Implemented a multidisciplinary communication board to communicate on patient’s mobility status.
3. Piloted tango commodes for use in OCH wards.
4. Introduced a monthly Falls Free Award and CEO award for wards with zero falls for 3 months.
5. Identified fall champions at each ward to reinforce the fall prevention practices to ground staff.
6. Placed signage on toilet doors and shower doors to remind staff and patients that patients should not be left alone in toilets.

title: Reducing Inpatient Falls In Och
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The workgroup has implemented the following interventions:
1. Established a high fall ward for patients with high fall risk.
2. Implemented a multidisciplinary communication board to communicate on patient’s mobility status.
3. Piloted tango commodes for use in OCH wards.
4. Introduced a monthly Falls Free Award and CEO award for wards with zero falls for 3 months.
5. Identified fall champions at each ward to reinforce the fall prevention practices to ground staff.
6. Placed signage on toilet doors and shower doors to remind staff and patients that patients should not be left alone in toilets.
7. Piloted TEMI robots to display fall prevention messages and videos to patients.
8. Conducted role play sessions post-fall incidents for learning purposes among nurses.
9. Organized Nurse-led Interprofessional Education (IPE) on managing dementia patients.

title: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
year: 2024
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
Step 1: We designed a mobility signage with concise information of patient’s functional mobility and pictograms of the transfers and walking aids to be hung at the patient’s bedside:
Step 2: We briefed our Physiotherapists on how to fill up mobility signage after functional assessment.
Step 3: Orientated our nurses in pilot ward to mobility signage and explained the mobility terms used during their roll call.

title: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
year: 2024
section: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM

Content:
“There is no time!” • Each 5 minutes spent on finding mobility status in SCM for each patient could easily add up to a significant amount of time. Time that nursing staff do not have. “Where is the information?” • Different physiotherapists write their mobility information in different areas of the notes. “Is my minimal assist the same as yours?” • Discrepancy in knowledge of patient’s current mobility status could potentially result in unsafe mobilization of patients thereby increasing risk of patient falls.||CHUNK 12 || SECTION: CONCLUSION || TITLE: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls || YEAR: 2024 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_CO005 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

section: CONCLUSION

Content:
Therefore, we conclude that mobility signage is a simple and effective communication tool between physiotherapists and ward staff allowing for patients to be mobilized with the correct level of assistance. With fast access to patient’s mobility status, there is quicker and safer decision-making by ward staff as the time saved can easily be up to 5 mins for each patient.||CHUNK 13 || SECTION: OUTCOME || TITLE: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls || YEAR: 2024 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_CO005 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

Content:
Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization in a Pilot Ward to Reduce Patient Falls Chua1, Chia1, Marilyn Cheryll Thang1, Yeo1, Ling-Jun2, Juliana Gladys Chen Koh Khee Xuan2 1Department of Physiotherapy, 2Department of Nursing
chunk_3:
[section: METHODOLOGY, project_code: SHM_CO005, year: 2024, hospital: SKH, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:
source: SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization in a Pilot Ward to Reduce Patient Falls.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T15:52:59.894244
project_code: SHM_CO005
hospital: SKH
title: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
year: 2024
section: METHODOLOGY

Content:
Step 1: We designed a mobility signage with concise information of patient’s functional mobility and pictograms of the transfers and walking aids to be hung at the patient’s bedside:
Step 2: We briefed our Physiotherapists on how to fill up mobility signage after functional assessment.
Step 3: Orientated our nurses in pilot ward to mobility signage and explained the mobility terms used during their roll call.
Step 4: Monthly follow-up surveys completed by ward staff and nursing students, and collection of patient fall statistics during period of pilot study. (*Follow up surveys conducted every month from Oct 2022 to Dec 2022)

title: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
year: 2024
section: INTRODUCTION

Content:
We know that immobility during inpatient stay does not aid in a patient’s recovery. Between physiotherapists and nursing staff, we play a big part in getting the patient to move.

However, there is a breakdown in getting the mobility information from physiotherapy notes in Sunrise Clinical Manager (SCM) to the nurses.

[section: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS, project_code: SHM_CO005, year: 2024, hospital: SKH, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:

title: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
year: 2024
section: ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS

Content:
The root cause lies in the inefficiency and inconsistency in how mobility information is recorded and communicated between physiotherapists and nurses, leading to potential miscommunication and delays that can impact patient safety and recovery.

The mobility signage system helped improve confidence among staff in handling patient transfers and increased overall mobility among patients. This was seen through reduced use of diapers and commodes as well as an increase in patient walking activity.

[section: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM, project_code: SHM_CO005, year: 2024, hospital: SKH, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:

hospital: SKH
title: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
year: 2024
section: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM

Content:
“There is no time!” • Each 5 minutes spent on finding mobility status in SCM for each patient could easily add up to a significant amount of time. Time that nursing staff do not have. “Where is the information?” • Different physiotherapists write their mobility information in different areas of the notes. “Is my minimal assist the same as yours?” • Discrepancy in knowledge of patient’s current mobility status could potentially result in unsafe mobilization of patients thereby increasing risk of patient falls.
chunk_12:
[section: CONCLUSION, project_code: SHM_CO005, year: 2024, hospital: SKH, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:
source: SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization in a Pilot Ward to Reduce Patient Falls.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T15:52:59.894244
project_code: SHM_CO005
hospital: SKH
title: Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
year: 2024
section: CONCLUSION

Content:
Therefore, we conclude that mobility signage is a simple and effective communication tool between physiotherapists and ward staff allowing for patients to be mobilized with the correct level of assistance. With fast access to patient’s mobility status, there is quicker and safer decision-making by ward staff as the time saved can easily be up to 5 mins for each patient.

section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
• Revision of Nasogastric (NG) Feeds Regime: Last NG feeds regime scheduled at 11pm instead of 12 midnight and feeding via NG tube moved to 8am from the original 6am-7am.
• Adjustment of nurses’ activity (to include elimination rounds): Night duty nurse to do Capillary Blood Glucose (CBG), bring ambulating patient to toilet, sit out of bed for gargle and breakfast. Morning duty nurse to assist in changing/turning bedbound patients and prepare for oral care and breakfast.
• Implementation of reminder card placed at nurses’ counter desktops and computer-on-wheels (COWs).||CHUNK 2 || SECTION: ANALYSIS OF PROBLEM || TITLE: Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SKH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM001 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

project_code: SHM_RM001
hospital: SKH
title: Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
• Revision of Nasogastric (NG) Feeds Regime: Last NG feeds regime scheduled at 11pm instead of 12 midnight and feeding via NG tube moved to 8am from the original 6am-7am.
• Adjustment of nurses’ activity (to include elimination rounds): Night duty nurse to do Capillary Blood Glucose (CBG), bring ambulating patient to toilet, sit out of bed for gargle and breakfast. Morning duty nurse to assist in changing/turning bedbound patients and prepare for oral care and breakfast.
• Implementation of reminder card placed at nurses’ counter desktops and computer-on-wheels (COWs).

test_query: Get me the methods of the posters on falls
llm_output:
The retrieved documents contain methodologies for several projects aimed at reducing inpatient falls, including detailed steps and analyses.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM001_SKH - Reducing Inpatient Falls Related To Toileting Need
- Identified that elimination rounds were either delayed or not carried out due to nurses being occupied with other duties such as feeding patients via Nasogastric Tube (NGT) at 12 midnight, taking bloods at 6am - 7am.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_RM044_SCH - Reducing Inpatient Falls In Och
- Conducted a root cause analysis in June 2020 to identify various factors leading to falls at OCH.

PROJECT TITLE: SHM_CO005_SKH - Encouraging Safe Active Mobilization In A Pilot Ward To Reduce Patient Falls
- Designed mobility signage with concise information of patient’s functional mobility and pictograms.
- Briefed Physiotherapists on how to fill up the mobility signage after a functional assessment.
- Orientated nurses in the pilot ward about the mobility signage during their roll call.
- Conducted monthly follow-up surveys by ward staff and nursing students from Oct 2022 to Dec 2022.

No detailed methodologies were found for SHM_RM052_SCH, but it focuses on reducing fall rates at SKCH.

CHUNK 1 || SECTION: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES || TITLE: Reducing Inpatient Falls In Och || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SCH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM044 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:
source: SHM_RM044_SCH - Reducing inpatient falls in OCH.pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:14:03.643599
project_code: SHM_RM044
hospital: SCH
title: Reducing Inpatient Falls In Och
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The workgroup has implemented the following interventions:
1. Established a high fall ward for patients with high fall risk.
2. Implemented a multidisciplinary communication board to communicate on patient’s mobility status.
3. Piloted tango commodes for use in OCH wards.
4. Introduced a monthly Falls Free Award and CEO award for wards with zero falls for 3 months.
5. Identified fall champions at each ward to reinforce the fall prevention practices to ground staff.
6. Placed signage on toilet doors and shower doors to remind staff and patients that patients should not be left alone in toilets.
7. Piloted TEMI robots to display fall prevention messages and videos to patients.
8. Conducted role play sessions post-fall incidents for learning purposes among nurses.
9. Organized Nurse-led Interprofessional Education (IPE) on managing dementia patients.||CHUNK 2 || SECTION: INTRODUCTION || TITLE: Reducing Inpatient Falls In Och || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SCH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM044 || RELEVANCE: 0.6 || CONTENT: Metadata:

project_code: SHM_RM044
hospital: SCH
title: Reducing Inpatient Falls In Och
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The workgroup has implemented the following interventions:
1. Established a high fall ward for patients with high fall risk.
2. Implemented a multidisciplinary communication board to communicate on patient’s mobility status.
3. Piloted tango commodes for use in OCH wards.
4. Introduced a monthly Falls Free Award and CEO award for wards with zero falls for 3 months.
5. Identified fall champions at each ward to reinforce the fall prevention practices to ground staff.
6. Placed signage on toilet doors and shower doors to remind staff and patients that patients should not be left alone in toilets.
7. Piloted TEMI robots to display fall prevention messages and videos to patients.
8. Conducted role play sessions post-fall incidents for learning purposes among nurses.
9. Organized Nurse-led Interprofessional Education (IPE) on managing dementia patients.

test_query: What are the projects that aim to bring down medication incident rate.
llm_output:
There are two projects aimed at reducing the medication incident rate.

PROJECT TITLE: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (OCH) [SHM_RM045]
- Focuses on decreasing medication incidents in OCH
- Aims to improve patient safety through better medication management

PROJECT TITLE: Reduce Medication Rate At Skch To Below 0.3 Per 1000 Patient Days (Ch Average) Over 1Yr [SHM_RM053]
- Seeks to lower the medication incident rate at SKCH
- Targets a reduction below 0.3 incidents per 1000 patient days over one year

CHUNK 1 || SECTION: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES || TITLE: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och) || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SCH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM045 || RELEVANCE: 0.9 || CONTENT: Metadata:
source: SHM_RM045_SCH - Reducing medication incident rate in Outram Community Hospital (OCH).pdf
processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:15:06.467446
project_code: SHM_RM045
hospital: SCH
title: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The project team brainstormed and came out with the following interventions:
1. A medication safety workgroup was formed to look into all medication safety related issues. Incidents were discussed with root cause analysis, and corrective actions were proposed at workgroup level.
2. SCH monthly medication safety bulletin has been published to share best practices and correct procedures to ensure medication safety.
3. Medication safety vest was piloted in selected OCH wards with the aim to reduce disruptions during medication administration. The intervention was not implemented due to unsatisfactory pilot results.
4. To implement a “status board” in SCM as a “live” board to keep staff updated on the list of tasks for patients.
5. Medication safety champions at each ward were identified to further reduce the risk of medication incidents. The champions will reinforce correct procedures to ground staff and create awareness. At the same time, they will communicate with their colleagues on new medication practices if any.
6. Complicated medications scheduling in SCM will be scheduled by the medical team, which will then be verified by pharmacists prior to nursing administration.||CHUNK 2 || SECTION: SUSTAINABILITY AND SPREAD || TITLE: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och) || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SCH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM045 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

hospital: SCH
title: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)
year: 2022
section: SUSTAINABILITY AND SPREAD

Content:
The medication safety champions in individual wards are able to reinforce medication safety practices to their colleagues. Staff will comply with medication administration process when correct practices have been consistently highlighted to them.
The monthly SCH medication bulletins have been sharing the correct medication safety practices with all staff. Group Comms have adapted one of the SCH bulletins to an article for HealthXchange on the topic of “Do Not Crush medications”. This can enhance cross-learning at SingHealth.||CHUNK 3 || SECTION: BACKGROUND || TITLE: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och) || YEAR: 2022 || HOSPITAL: SCH || PROJECT_CODE: SHM_RM045 || RELEVANCE: 0.8 || CONTENT: Metadata:

processing_timestamp: 2025-04-26T16:15:06.467446
project_code: SHM_RM045
hospital: SCH
title: Reducing Medication Incident Rate In Outram Community Hospital (Och)
year: 2022
section: INTERVENTIONS / INITIATIVES

Content:
The project team brainstormed and came out with the following interventions:
1. A medication safety workgroup was formed to look into all medication safety related issues. Incidents were discussed with root cause analysis, and corrective actions were proposed at workgroup level.
2. SCH monthly medication safety bulletin has been published to share best practices and correct procedures to ensure medication safety.
3. Medication safety vest was piloted in selected OCH wards with the aim to reduce disruptions during medication administration. The intervention was not implemented due to unsatisfactory pilot results.
4. To implement a “status board” in SCM as a “live” board to keep staff updated on the list of tasks for patients.
5. Medication safety champions at each ward were identified to further reduce the risk of medication incidents. The champions will reinforce correct procedures to ground staff and create awareness. At the same time, they will communicate with their colleagues on new medication practices if any.
6. Complicated medications scheduling in SCM will be scheduled by the medical team, which will then be verified by pharmacists prior to nursing administration.

[section: SUSTAINABILITY AND SPREAD, project_code: SHM_RM045, year: 2022, hospital: SCH, relevance: 0.8] Metadata:
